title-group.article-title: Some Aspects of Christian Mystical Rhetoric, Philosophy, and Poetry

Courtland Baker, the latter of whom provocatively observes: "Even if the entire literature and thought of antiquity had perished, it is entirely conceivable to suppose that the poetry of the late Middle Ages and of the Renaissance would have contained, nonetheless, an avowal of belief in the divine participation of the human creative mind with that of Deity, so firmly rooted is this belief in certain characteristic modes of thought inherent in Christian doc- trine" (1939,301).
